topic.title: Introduction

body.p: This document describes the block layer simulator (BSim) which utilizes the host simulation library (HostSim) to issue NVM Express (NVMe) commands to the NVM controller firmware running on the architectural simulator (ArchSim).

BSim is a native Linux application written in 'C' and distributed in source, making it simple to extend and easy to maintain. When started, BSim presents the user with a simple command prompt interface allowing them to issue a single NVMe command at a time. Multiple NVMe commands may be listed in a text file and executed one after the other by invoking the text file via the BSim command prompt or by specifying the text file on the BSim command line when BSim is started.

BSim does not include any advanced parsing or scripting capabilities. Any complex chaining of NVMe commands or error status checking should be implemented in 'C' and invoked from the BSim command prompt via a top-level custom command.

BSim communicates via the HostSim library to ArchSim over TCP/IP, effectively sending and receiving PCI Express (PCIe) packets over the network, this means that it is not necessary to run BSim on the same physical Linux host as ArchSim.
body.note: The BSim command prompt interface relies on the argtable2 third-party shared library. This library must be downloaded, compiled, and installed on the same Linux host as BSim. The argtable2 sources may be downloaded from http://argtable.sourceforge.net/
